description: Regrettable vs non-regrettable attrition tracking, exit interview themes, retention metrics.
verificationMethod: Cross-reference HRIS records with exit interview data and manager classification of regrettable vs non-regrettable.
gamingRisk: Low — data is system-generated. Main risk: managers misclassifying departures as 'non-regrettable' to hide retention failures.

description: Compliance audit results, access review logs, or security scan reports.
verificationMethod: Audit logs are system-generated with timestamps and immutable records. Verify log source and date range.
gamingRisk: Very low — system-generated, tamper-resistant. Cannot be fabricated without system access.

description: Calendar patterns showing meeting cadence, 1:1 frequency, or focus time allocation.
verificationMethod: Cross-reference calendar entries with meeting notes or attendee confirmation. Calendar events alone prove scheduling, not attendance or quality.
gamingRisk: High — calendar events can be created retroactively. Proves scheduling intent, not actual meeting quality or outcomes.

description: Launch readiness checklist, security review checklist, or onboarding checklist.
verificationMethod: Verify checklist was completed before the event (not retroactively). Check timestamps and cross-reference with launch/deploy records.
gamingRisk: Medium — checklists can be filled out retroactively or rubber-stamped. Verify completion predates the event it governs.

description: Structured communication plan for re-orgs, launches, incidents, or major changes.
verificationMethod: Verify the plan existed before the event, not after. Cross-reference with actual communications sent and stakeholder feedback on clarity.
gamingRisk: Medium — plans can be written retroactively. Verify creation date predates the event and that stakeholders confirm they received the communications.

description: Live or screenshot of monitoring/tracking dashboard (DORA, team health, cost, etc.).
verificationMethod: Access the live dashboard directly. For screenshots, verify the dashboard exists and matches the screenshot. Check data freshness and source.
gamingRisk: Low — dashboards pull from real systems. Main risk: cherry-picking favorable time windows or filtering data to hide problems.

description: Formal decision record: DACI, RFC, ADR, trade-off analysis, or investment proposal.
verificationMethod: Verify document creation date, check version history for authorship, and confirm stakeholders listed actually participated in the decision.
gamingRisk: Low — documents have version history and stakeholder signatures. Fabrication would require collaboration from multiple parties.

description: Technical design doc, architecture proposal, or system design review artifact.
verificationMethod: Check document version history, review comments, and cross-reference with implemented system. Verify the design preceded implementation.
gamingRisk: Low — design docs have review trails and are cross-referenced by implementation. Post-hoc documentation is detectable through version history.

description: Written artifact: strategy doc, tech spec, design doc, RFC, ADR, or similar.
verificationMethod: Check document creation date, authorship, version history, and comments. Verify the document was shared with and reviewed by its intended audience.
gamingRisk: Low — most documentation platforms track creation date, edits, and comments. A document with no comments or views is suspect.

description: Email thread demonstrating communication, alignment, escalation, or stakeholder management.
verificationMethod: Verify email headers, timestamps, and recipient list. Cross-reference with recipients' confirmation of the communication.
gamingRisk: Low — emails have immutable timestamps and recipient lists. Main risk: selective sharing of favorable threads while hiding contradictory ones.

description: Interview rubric, hiring bar documentation, or role scorecard.
verificationMethod: Verify the guide was created before hiring loops began. Cross-reference with actual interview scorecards to confirm interviewers used it.
gamingRisk: Medium — guides can be created but not followed. Verify through interviewer feedback and scorecard consistency.

description: Sev1/Sev2 incident report, timeline, or post-incident review.
verificationMethod: Cross-reference with incident management system (PagerDuty, Opsgenie) timestamps. Verify action items have owners and deadlines.
gamingRisk: Very low — incidents are system-triggered events with external evidence. Reports may omit root causes but the incident itself is verifiable.

description: Hiring loop feedback, bar raiser notes, or interview calibration records.
verificationMethod: Verify scorecards were submitted before debrief (independent scoring). Check that scores include specific behavioral examples, not just ratings.
gamingRisk: Medium — scorecards can be vague or influenced by groupthink in debrief. Independent pre-debrief submission reduces this risk.

description: Notes from 1:1s, team meetings, skip-levels, calibration sessions, or retrospectives.
verificationMethod: Verify notes were shared with attendees for accuracy. Cross-reference with calendar events and action item follow-through.
gamingRisk: Medium — notes reflect the author's perspective. Mitigate by sharing notes with attendees for confirmation and tracking action item completion.

description: Quantitative measurement: DORA metrics, SLO data, sprint velocity, attrition rates, etc.
verificationMethod: Access the metric source system directly. Verify the measurement methodology, time period, and scope match the claim.
gamingRisk: Low for system-generated metrics. Main risks: cherry-picking favorable time windows, changing measurement methodology mid-period, or reporting team-level metrics as individual achievement.

description: Informal note, observation log, or personal record of event/decision.
verificationMethod: Corroborate with other evidence sources. A note alone is a claim; a note backed by a metric or peer feedback is evidence.
gamingRisk: High — notes are self-authored with no external validation. Should always be paired with stronger evidence types.

description: PagerDuty/OpsGenie metrics: page frequency, off-hours pages, MTTA/MTTR, rotation health.
verificationMethod: Pull directly from incident management platform. System-generated with immutable timestamps.
gamingRisk: Very low — system-generated. Main risk: suppressing alerts to artificially reduce page counts (detectable through SLO breaches without corresponding alerts).

description: Team topology diagram, reporting structure, or ownership map.
verificationMethod: Cross-reference with HRIS data and service ownership registries. Verify the chart reflects current state, not aspirational structure.
gamingRisk: Medium — org charts can show aspirational structures that don't match reality. Verify against actual reporting relationships and service ownership.

description: Structured feedback from PM, Design, peer EMs, skip-level reports, or cross-functional partners.
verificationMethod: Verify feedback was solicited from a representative set of peers (not just allies). Check that feedback includes specific examples, not just general praise.
gamingRisk: Medium — feedback can be selectively solicited from favorable sources. Mitigate by requiring feedback from cross-functional partners and skip-level reports, not just direct reports.

description: CI/CD pipeline configuration, deployment automation, or release process artifact.
verificationMethod: Inspect the actual pipeline configuration in the repository. Verify the pipeline runs successfully and is actively used (check recent run history).
gamingRisk: Medium — a pipeline can exist but not be used, or can be configured but never enforced. Check execution history and success rates.

description: Blameless post-mortem document with root cause, action items, and follow-up tracking.
verificationMethod: Cross-reference with incident management system. Verify action items have owners, deadlines, and completion tracking. Check that follow-through happened.
gamingRisk: Low — post-mortems reference real incidents. Main risk: quality theater — well-written post-mortems with no action item follow-through. Check completion rates.

description: Code review PR demonstrating review culture, SLA compliance, or knowledge distribution.
verificationMethod: Access the PR directly in the repository. Check timestamps, reviewer engagement quality, and whether comments were substantive.
gamingRisk: Medium — PRs can receive rubber-stamp approvals. A PR with 'LGTM' comments proves process compliance but not review quality.

description: Slide deck from exec review, business review, team all-hands, or planning presentation.
verificationMethod: Verify the presentation was actually delivered (check calendar, attendee list). Cross-reference claims in slides with source data.
gamingRisk: Medium — slides can present curated narratives. Verify data claims against source systems and check that the presentation was delivered to its stated audience.

description: Team health survey, engagement survey, onboarding NPS, or pulse survey results.
verificationMethod: Access raw survey results (not just summary). Check response rate (>70% for validity), question phrasing for bias, and trend data across multiple surveys.
gamingRisk: Medium — survey results can be influenced by survey timing, question framing, or social pressure. Low response rates reduce validity. Verify response rates and question neutrality.

description: Notes from manager-report 1:1s covering career development, performance feedback, or coaching conversations.
verificationMethod: Verify notes were shared with the direct report. Cross-reference with action items that were followed through. Check consistency across multiple 1:1s.
gamingRisk: Medium — notes reflect the manager's perspective. Mitigate by confirming key takeaways with the direct report and tracking action item completion.

description: Written career development plan with gap analysis, milestones, and evidence targets for the next level.
verificationMethod: Verify the plan was co-created with the direct report, has specific milestones with dates, and is reviewed at regular intervals.
gamingRisk: Medium — plans can exist on paper without action. Check milestone completion and whether the engineer confirms the plan is actively guiding their development.

description: Formal HR documentation: PIP records, exit documentation, headcount approvals, or compensation adjustment records.
verificationMethod: Access through HRIS system. HR documents have formal approval chains and timestamps.
gamingRisk: Very low — HR documents go through formal approval processes with multiple stakeholders and legal review.

description: Written OKR document with measurable key results, progress tracking, and quarterly outcomes.
verificationMethod: Verify OKRs were published at quarter start (not retroactively). Check that key results are measurable and progress was tracked throughout the quarter.
gamingRisk: Medium — OKRs can be sandbagged (set easy targets) or retroactively adjusted. Verify creation date predates the quarter and targets were unchanged.

description: Roadmap, capacity plan, resource allocation model, sprint plan, or quarterly planning document.
verificationMethod: Verify the plan was created before execution began. Cross-reference planned outcomes with actual results to assess planning accuracy.
gamingRisk: Medium — plans can be written retroactively to match outcomes. Verify creation timestamps and check for version history showing the plan preceded execution.

description: Documented process, runbook, decision framework, onboarding guide, or team working agreement.
verificationMethod: Verify the artifact is actively used (not just documented). Check last-updated date, team reference frequency, and onboarding feedback citing it.
gamingRisk: Medium — processes can be documented but not followed. Verify through team feedback and observable adherence to the documented process.

description: Action items, decisions, and improvement commitments from team retrospectives.
verificationMethod: Verify action items have owners, deadlines, and completion tracking. Cross-reference with actual process changes that resulted from retrospective decisions.
gamingRisk: Medium — retrospectives can produce action items that are never followed through. Check completion rates and whether improvements are measurable.

description: Performance review document, calibration case, or promotion packet with evidence-based assessment.
verificationMethod: Verify the review was completed on time, includes specific behavioral examples, and was discussed with the direct report. Cross-reference with calibration outcomes.
gamingRisk: Medium — reviews can be inflated or deflated. Mitigate through calibration committee cross-review and skip-level confirmation that feedback was delivered.

description: Written team charter covering mission, working agreements, decision-making authority, and communication norms.
verificationMethod: Verify the charter was co-created with the team (not imposed top-down). Check that team members reference it in practice and that it's reviewed periodically.
gamingRisk: Medium — charters can be written as performative exercises. Verify through team survey data confirming alignment with charter norms and periodic review cadence.

description: Team-specific survey data: team health check, psychological safety assessment, or team-level engagement pulse.
verificationMethod: Verify response rate (>70% for validity), question neutrality, and that results are shared with the team along with an action plan.
gamingRisk: Medium — team surveys are subject to social desirability bias, especially with small teams where anonymity is difficult. Pair with skip-level feedback for validation.
